description: A five-slide presentation with key information about the Wolf.
title: All About the Wolf

slides.title: Introduction to the Wolf
slides.content: The wolf (Canis lupus) is a large canine native to Eurasia and North America. It is the largest extant member of the Canidae family and an apex predator that plays a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem balance. Wolves are highly social animals known for their complex pack structure.

slides.title: Physical Characteristics
content: Gray wolves are the most common species, typically weighing 80-120 pounds with shoulder heights of 2-3 feet.
They have powerful jaws capable of generating 1,500 psi of pressure, strong legs for covering great distances, and excellent endurance.

slides.title: Pack Structure and Communication
content: Wolves live in family groups called packs, typically consisting of 5-11 animals led by an alpha breeding pair.
They communicate through a complex system of howls, body language, scent marking, and facial expressions to coordinate hunting and maintain social bonds.

slides.title: Hunting Behavior
content: Wolves are cursorial hunters that rely on stamina rather than speed, often working together to take down large prey like elk, deer, and moose.
A single wolf can consume up to 20 pounds of meat at one feeding, and packs can travel 30-50 miles while hunting.

slides.title: Conservation and Cultural Significance
content: Wolves were nearly extinct in many areas due to hunting and habitat loss but have made significant comebacks in some regions.
They hold deep cultural significance in many human societies, appearing in folklore, mythology, and as symbols of wilderness and freedom.
